problem: If $5$ lunks can be traded for $3$ kunks, and $2$ kunks will buy $4$ apples, how many lunks are needed to purchase one dozen apples?
solution: One dozen apples is 12 apples, which costs $2\cdot3=6$ kunks (since 4 apples cost 2 kunks), which costs $5\cdot2=\boxed{10}$ lunks (since 3 kunks cost 5 lunks).
chatgpt_solution:
Since $2$ kunks will buy $4$ apples, then $1$ kunk will buy $2$ apples.  Similarly, swapping $5$ lunks for $3$ kunks is the same as swapping $1\frac{2}{5}$ lunks for $2$ kunks, which we know will buy $4$ apples.  Hence we see that $4$ apples can be traded for $1\frac{2}{5}$ lunks. 

Since $1 \frac{2}{5}$ lunks will buy $4$ apples, we see that $1$ lunk will buy $\frac{4}{1 \frac{2}{5}} = \frac{20}{7}$ apples.  We have \begin{align*}
1\text{ lunk} &= \frac{20}{7}\text{ apples}, \\
\frac{7}{20}\text{ lunk} &= 1\text{ apple}.
\end{align*}Hence, we see that a dozen, or $12$ apples, will be $\dfrac{7}{20}\cdot12 = \boxed{4\frac{1}{5}}$ lunks.
